ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about theater broadly speaking, but also about the history of tragedy in the European literary tradition - as the course name suggests. My ability to consider works of literature comparatively and in different contexts improved a lot. I also learned to think critically about writing and writers and to relate the reading of a work of theater to its staging.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings worked well together and revealed interesting patterns. The discussion was lively and very well led. I think it's always tricky when planning a survey course like this one to balance a desire to group works chronologically with a desire to group works by movement or by similar characteristics. By and large, though, I thought the order of works made sense and was conducive to discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion felt intimate and real despite the Zoom barrier. Professor Trumpener shared images and videos and encouraged us to bring visual sources of our own: interesting productions of works discussed in class, posters advertising productions of works discussed in class, etc. Professor Trumpener also used the chat efficiently to share key terms, especially in foreign languages, which was really helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I'd recommend this course to anyone, but especially to students interested in literature, history, art, theater, foreign language, and the arts and humanities more broadly. I think looking at a single literary category over time provides a good balance of the general with the specific; I came out of this course feeling like I'd learned a lot, not only about literature in general, but also about the history of German theater, for instance.

If you are interested in literature, I definitely recommend this course. I was a little hesitant to take this class at first because it was focused entirely on theater, but I found that reading theater - a kind of novel minus the narrative descriptions - was really helpful in terms of thinking about writing and literature as a whole. I enjoyed thinking about speech, set design and stage directions, and it was particularly interesting to see the evolution and development of these ideas from the ancient Greeks to the modern day.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The course was just a virtual seminar. It was heavily discussion-based; we also gave short, casual presentations on videos or images and wrote two papers.
